educational_objective: Diagnose combined pulmonary fibrosis and emphysema.
question_text: A 71-year-old woman with gastroesophageal reflux disease is evaluated for worsening dyspnea and cough. She has a longtime history of cigarette smoking. Lung auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles.High-resolution CT scans of the chest are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is combined pulmonary fibrosis and emphysema (CPFE) (Option C). High-resolution CT is the preferred diagnostic modality to demonstrate the changes seen in CPFE, including upper lobe emphysema (left panel, blue arrows) and lower lobe fibrosis (right panel, red arrows). The pulmonary fibrosis is demonstrated by the bilateral, peripheral, subpleural, and basal-predominant septal line thickening (reticulations) with honeycomb changes.In contrast, bilateral pneumonia would show more consolidative opacities and would not necessarily be subpleural. Bronchiectasis would show multiple dilated and thick-walled bronchi with a signet ring appearance (when the diameter of the bronchus in cross-section is larger than the adjacent pulmonary artery), lack of normal tapering in diameter of many bronchi, and mucus-filled bronchi. Pulmonary edema is typically more diffuse homogeneous, affecting both the upper and lower lobes.
